trans-unit.source: Specifying the Range Header for File Service Operations
trans-unit.target: Specifying the Range Header for File Service Operations

trans-unit.source: Some File service GET operations support the use of the standard HTTP <parameterReference>Range</parameterReference> header.
trans-unit.target: Some File service GET operations support the use of the standard HTTP <parameterReference>Range</parameterReference> header.

trans-unit.source: Many HTTP clients, including the .NET client library, limit the size of the <parameterReference>Range</parameterReference> header to a 32-bit integer, and thus its value is limited to a maximum of 4 GB.
trans-unit.target: Many HTTP clients, including the .NET client library, limit the size of the <parameterReference>Range</parameterReference> header to a 32-bit integer, and thus its value is limited to a maximum of 4 GB.

trans-unit.source: Since files can be larger than 4 GB in size, the File service accepts a custom range header <parameterReference>x-ms-range</parameterReference> for any operation that takes an HTTP <parameterReference>Range</parameterReference> header.
trans-unit.target: Since files can be larger than 4 GB in size, the File service accepts a custom range header <parameterReference>x-ms-range</parameterReference> for any operation that takes an HTTP <parameterReference>Range</parameterReference> header.

trans-unit.source: Some HTTP clients, including the Microsoft Silverlight library, limit access to the <parameterReference>Range</parameterReference> header altogether.
trans-unit.target: Some HTTP clients, including the Microsoft Silverlight library, limit access to the <parameterReference>Range</parameterReference> header altogether.

trans-unit.source: The <parameterReference>x-ms-range</parameterReference> header can be used to circumvent these limitations as well.
trans-unit.target: The <parameterReference>x-ms-range</parameterReference> header can be used to circumvent these limitations as well.

trans-unit.source: If the <parameterReference>x-ms-range</parameterReference> header is specified on a request, then the service uses the range specified by <parameterReference>x-ms-range</parameterReference>; otherwise, the range specified by the <parameterReference>Range</parameterReference> header is used.
trans-unit.target: If the <parameterReference>x-ms-range</parameterReference> header is specified on a request, then the service uses the range specified by <parameterReference>x-ms-range</parameterReference>; otherwise, the range specified by the <parameterReference>Range</parameterReference> header is used.

trans-unit.source: Range Header Formats
trans-unit.target: Range Header Formats

trans-unit.source: The File service accepts two byte ranges for the <parameterReference>Range</parameterReference> and <parameterReference>x-ms-range</parameterReference> headers.
trans-unit.target: The File service accepts two byte ranges for the <parameterReference>Range</parameterReference> and <parameterReference>x-ms-range</parameterReference> headers.

trans-unit.source: The byte range must adhere to either of the following formats for the headers:
trans-unit.target: The byte range must adhere to either of the following formats for the headers:

trans-unit.source: Format 1: bytes=startByte-
trans-unit.target: Format 1: bytes=startByte-

trans-unit.source: This range will return bytes from the offset <parameterReference>startByte</parameterReference> through the end of the file.
trans-unit.target: This range will return bytes from the offset <parameterReference>startByte</parameterReference> through the end of the file.

trans-unit.source: For example, to specify a range encompassing all bytes after the first 256 bytes of a file, you can pass in either of the following headers:
trans-unit.target: For example, to specify a range encompassing all bytes after the first 256 bytes of a file, you can pass in either of the following headers:

trans-unit.source: The <parameterReference>Content-Length</parameterReference> header in the response is equal to the number of bytes from the offset until the end of the file.
trans-unit.target: The <parameterReference>Content-Length</parameterReference> header in the response is equal to the number of bytes from the offset until the end of the file.

trans-unit.source: Using the example range above for a file of 1,024 bytes in length, <parameterReference>Content-Length</parameterReference> would be 756.
trans-unit.target: Using the example range above for a file of 1,024 bytes in length, <parameterReference>Content-Length</parameterReference> would be 756.

trans-unit.source: If the offset is valid and does not exceed the file’s total length, the request will return an status code 206 (Partial Content).
trans-unit.target: If the offset is valid and does not exceed the file’s total length, the request will return an status code 206 (Partial Content).

trans-unit.source: If the offset is invalid and exceeds the file’s total length, the request will return status code 416 (Requested Range Not Satisfiable).
trans-unit.target: If the offset is invalid and exceeds the file’s total length, the request will return status code 416 (Requested Range Not Satisfiable).

trans-unit.source: Format 2: bytes=startByte-endByte
trans-unit.target: Format 2: bytes=startByte-endByte

trans-unit.source: This range will return bytes from the offset <parameterReference>startByte</parameterReference> through <parameterReference>endByte</parameterReference>.
trans-unit.target: This range will return bytes from the offset <parameterReference>startByte</parameterReference> through <parameterReference>endByte</parameterReference>.

trans-unit.source: For example, to specify a range encompassing the first 512 bytes of a file, you would pass in either of the following headers:
trans-unit.target: For example, to specify a range encompassing the first 512 bytes of a file, you would pass in either of the following headers:

trans-unit.source: The <parameterReference>Content-Length</parameterReference> header in the response is equal to the number of bytes between each offset.
trans-unit.target: The <parameterReference>Content-Length</parameterReference> header in the response is equal to the number of bytes between each offset.

trans-unit.source: Using the example range above for a file of 1,024 bytes in length, <parameterReference>Content-Length</parameterReference> would be 512.
trans-unit.target: Using the example range above for a file of 1,024 bytes in length, <parameterReference>Content-Length</parameterReference> would be 512.

trans-unit.source: If the offset is valid and does not exceed the file’s total length, the request will return an status code 206 (Partial Content).
trans-unit.target: If the offset is valid and does not exceed the file’s total length, the request will return an status code 206 (Partial Content).

trans-unit.source: If the offset is invalid and exceeds the file’s total length, the request will return status code 416 (Requested Range Not Satisfiable).
trans-unit.target: If the offset is invalid and exceeds the file’s total length, the request will return status code 416 (Requested Range Not Satisfiable).
